Triggering Event: "She straightened up from stocking the shelves, the familiar creak of her knees echoing in the quiet store. Glancing at the clock, she realized it was almost closing time. She hadn't called him today, too busy with the sudden rush of customers. A pang of remorse hit her as she imagined his worried face waiting for her call."
Generated Assessment: "What if he thinks I don't care? What if something happened to him today and he needed me? Fuck, why didn't I call? He might be worried sick. Or worse, what if he's pissed off now? Could lose him over this, dammit. Stupid shelves, stupid customers! Why does everything always have to be so fucking busy?"

Triggering Event: Every evening, he watches them through the shop window - a young couple laughing together, hands entwined, as they browse the very displays he's polished for decades. He sees their ease, their joy, and feels an ache in his chest that's become all too familiar since she passed.
Generated Assessment:
Writing Prompt: Describe your feelings as you watch them through the shop window each evening.

---

Goddammit, why do they always have to be so fucking happy? It's like they're rubbing it in my face, you know? Every goddamn night, I polish these displays, put everything just right, and then they waltz in here, hand in hand, laughing like the whole world belongs to them. Don't they know I can see them? Don't they care that it fucking hurts?

It's not like I asked for this. It wasn't my choice to be left alone, to watch them from the shadows while they live their goddamn perfect life right in front of me. I didn't ask for this ache in my chest, this constant reminder of what I don't have anymore.

Fuck them, fuck their happiness. They shouldn't be allowed to have it, not when I can't. It's not fair, it's just not fucking fair.

Triggering Event: "Opening another dusty box of old stock, he grimaces at the sight of a rotting banana peel stuck to a pair of once-white sneakers."
Generated Assessment: "I can't believe she left this mess for me to find. Like I don't have enough shit on my plate already."

Triggering Event: He found an unopened condom in her coat pocket, expired six months ago.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:** Imagine you're a nosy friend who found an unopened condom in your best friend's coat pocket, expired six months ago. You know she has a strict moral code about safe sex.

**Text:**
"Oh, for crying out loud! What's this doing here?" I plucked the foil packet from her coat, examining it like some ancient artifact. Expired? Six months? I could almost hear her thoughts, "Slutty, irresponsible, typical of you." But then again, she was always so judgmental, even in her own head. Guess she thought she could hide her little secrets from me. Well, not today, buddy! I'll show her who's really got their act together."

Triggering Event: "After a long, tiring shift at the hospital, he returns home to find their shared apartment empty and quiet, save for the faint hum of the refrigerator. His partner had texted they were working late, but the house still feels too large, too silent. He sits alone in the dimly lit living room, surrounded by shadows cast by the setting sun, his usual sense of companionship replaced by a heavy, lingering loneliness."
Generated Assessment: "He's either always here or never around," he muttered to himself, sinking into the couch with a sigh. The house felt like a museum exhibit tonight, each room echoing emptiness. It was either bustling with their shared laughter and stories, or it was this - a silent, hollow shell. There was no in-between, no halfway full or half-empty glass. Just extremes, always extremes."

Triggering Event: "On his way home, he noticed the graffiti on the wall of the hospital where he'd worked tirelessly for months. 'Quitter' was scrawled in red, a mocking echo of the rumours that had cost him his job. His knuckles tightened around his bag, a surge of vengefulness coursing through him."
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:** Imagine you're an outgoing nurse who's just been unfairly let go from your job due to rumors. You notice graffiti on the hospital wall that seems directed at you. Capture your immediate, emotional reaction.

**Text:**

I stormed past that damn wall like I owned it, but now my eyes keep snagging on those red letters, 'Quitter'. It's bold, mocking me. They think they know me, don't they? Like they were there when that hag from admin twisted her lips and whispered lies loud enough for the whole floor to hear. Quitter. I could see it in their eyes, everyone who'd known me, worked with me, now staring at me like I was some coward.

I didn't quit, damn it! I was pushed out. But how do they know that? How can they possibly understand when they weren't there, weren't part of the daily grind, the late nights, the lives I helped save? They don't see the truth. They never will because all they've got is a stupid word scrawled on some wall.

I'm not going to let them win. I'll show them. I'll prove it. But first... first, I need them to pay. Every single one of those ignorant fools who dared to judge me without knowing the facts. They deserve to know what it feels like.

Triggering Event: After meticulously preparing lunch, she sets it aside for her partner who's working from home. Hours pass with no sign of him. Irritation simmers as she realizes he's forgotten their agreed meal time yet again.
Generated Assessment: "You know what? Fuck it. I spend ages chopping veggies, marinating chicken, even remembered to take his goddamn lactose-free milk out of the fridge. And for what? For him to be head-deep in some bloody Zoom meeting like his life depends on it. Meanwhile, I'm over here, Martha Stewart incarnate, with a fucking 'best wife ever' apron on. Bet you none of those other partners are slaving away like this. They're probably enjoying some fancy takeout right about now."

Triggering Event: A patient he hadn't seen in years walked into his clinic, now unrecognizable due to severe weight loss and premature aging. He noticed his own reflection in the patient's eyes, a stark reminder of time passed and chances missed.
Generated Assessment: "Dammit! What if he'd just walked in here looking like his old self? Would've been nice, wouldn't it? But no, now I'm staring at a goddamn stranger with my reflection in his eyes. Fuck me sideways, what if that's me in twenty years? Shit, who knows what could happen tomorrow?"

Triggering Event: She returned home from her shift at the restaurant, tired but content with another job well done. As she stepped into her quiet apartment, she noticed the faint scent of something burning. She rushed to the kitchen, hoping it wasn't what she thought. It was. The plant she'd nurtured for years, a gift from her late sister, had been left too long without water. Its once vibrant green leaves were now shriveled and brown. Tears stung her eyes as she realized no one had noticed its decline, not even herself in her daily rush.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:**
Imagine you're a hardworking individual who recently lost your sister. You've been so busy with work that you haven't noticed your beloved plant, a gift from her, slowly wilting away.

**Text:**

I stood there, staring at what was once my pride and joy. It was like seeing a ghost of our past together. I could almost hear her voice, "Take care of it, okay? It's our little piece of green." But I hadn't. I'd been too caught up in my own world.

I looked around the apartment, wondering who had seen this happening. Had they thought, "Why didn't she notice?" Did they judge me for being so neglectful? I could feel their eyes on me, even though no one was there. The silence seemed to echo with unspoken words of blame.

Tears spilled over, not just for the plant, but for every moment I'd missed, every sign I'd ignored. It felt like everyone had noticed except me. How could they not think less of me? I knew what they were thinking.

Triggering Event: In the break room, she opens the communal fridge to find a moldy sandwich, its edges curling like worms. A sour smell hits her nostrils, and she feels bile rise in her throat as she hurriedly shoves it back inside before wiping her hands on her pants.
Generated Assessment:
In the quiet sanctum of the break room, I had intended to seize a moment's respite, perhaps indulge in a light repast before the day's labours resumed their relentless march. Yet, as I swung open the refrigerator door, I was greeted not by the crisp allure of chilled sustenance but an affront to my senses. There, nestled amongst our shared provisions, lay a sandwich in advanced stages of decay, its boundaries blurred by the insidious tendrils of mould. The sight alone seemed to sour my stomach, but it was nothing compared to the noxious fumes that assailed me, causing my nostrils to flare and recoil in unison. It was as if Nature herself had conspired to remind us all of her inevitable triumph over our transitory existence.

In a flurry of disgust, I thrust the offending item back into its icy tomb, slamming the door shut with perhaps more vehemence than was strictly necessary. My hands, now traitors to my cause, bore the stigmata of their encounter; they must be cleansed at once. With a brisk rub against my trousers, I attempted to erase the memory of that tactile violation.

I suppose it is not too much to ask for a little consideration from one's colleagues. After all, this is not some backwater outpost where hygiene standards are but loose suggestions; we are a team of professionals, bound together by mutual respect and shared goals. And yet, here I stand, a victim of our collective lapse in judgement, my stomach churning like the sea during a tempest.

But perhaps I am overreacting. It is but one sandwich, after all, and not even mine at that. Yet, as I cast a critical eye over the other items within our communal refrigerator, I cannot help but feel a creeping sense of unease. What else might be lurking in the shadows, hidden behind the facade of pristine packaging? The very thought makes my skin crawl.

No, I think it best to forgo my intended repast and instead make my way to the canteen. The food there may not be as fresh, but at least it is prepared by professionals who understand the importance of such niceties. And perhaps, just perhaps, I will mention this little incident to our facilities manager. A gentle reminder, if you will, that we are all in this together - and that includes maintaining a level of cleanliness befitting an establishment such as ours.

After all, it is not too much to ask for a little consideration from one's colleagues. Is it?
